data.title: 100 Adorable Names That Mean Dream
data.meta_description: Keep reading to discover 100 beautiful names that mean dream with various styles and origins, appealing to dreamers from across the globe.
data.text:
Aaru

In ancient Egyptian mythology, Aaru was a heavenly field of reeds where Osiris ruled. The Egyptians believed people’s souls would travel on a long and dangerous journey to the field. If they made it safely, they would live enjoyable lives for eternity. Perhaps your little Aaru will enter this heavenly realm whenever he drifts to sleep.

Origin: Egyptian

Meaning: Reed fields of paradise

Pronunciation: AIR-ooh

Variations: Ialu, Iaru

Ahlam

An elegant choice for your little dreamer, Ahlam’s often thought to mean “dreams” in Arabic. Other possible meanings are “witty” or “imaginative.” Ahlam suits a creative girl whose imaginative spirit will make her dreams come true!

Origin: Arabic

Meaning: Dreams

Namesakes: Ahlam bint Ali bin Hazeem Al Shamsi, an Emirati singer, and actress who was a judge on MBC’s Arab Idol.

Aisling

This Irish name is modern, first used at the start of the 20th-century. Aisling was popular in England and Ireland in the 1990s but has since fallen out of favor. Aislinn (a common variation) entered the U.S. charts in 2015 but is still relatively rare. If you’re looking for a dreamy name with the potential to become a U.S. fad, Aisling might be the winner.

Origin: Irish

Meaning: Dream, vision

Pronunciation: ASH-lyn

Variations: Aislinn, Ashling, Aislin

Namesakes: Aisling Cliodhnadh O’Sullivan, an Irish comedian, actress, and writer who wrote and starred in the comedy series This Way Up.

Popularity: Aisling received its highest ranking of 21st in Ireland in 1998, declining in popularity since.

Alice

Alice‘s association with Lewis Carroll’s famous novel, Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland (1865), earns it a place on our list of dream names. Perhaps your daughter’s dreams will be as vivid and colorful as Alice’s were.

Origin: French

Meaning: Noble type

Namesakes: Alice Sophia Eve, an English actress known for her roles in She’s Out of My League, Men in Black 3, and Star Trek Into Darkness.

Popularity: Alice’s popularity is rising, ranked the 64th most popular name for U.S. girls in 2021.

Almos

Your baby boy will sleep soundly with a strong name like Almos! Almos is associated with a semi-legendary ruler and uniter of the Hungarian tribes. Before Almos was born, his mother dreamt she was impregnated by a magical bird, who foretold her son would be a ruler of a great nation.

Origin: Hungarian

Meaning: Dream

Pronunciation: AL-mosh

Namesakes: Almos, the head of the Hungarian tribes from around 850 C.E.

Popularity: Almos peaked with a rating of 87th in Hungary in 2006.

Alora

Alora is used by Bantu-speaking peoples in Botswana and other parts of Africa. There are few names lovelier and more original than Alora for the little girl you’ve been dreaming of!

Origin: Bantu

Meaning: My dream

Variations: Elora

Namesakes: Alora Catherine Smith, an actress best known for her role in Rob Reiner’s movie, Flipped.

Popularity: Alora entered the U.S. charts in 2018, rising to 464th in 2021.

Amets

Amets comes from the Basque – a people group inhabiting the Basque Country of France and Spain. Amets has had little success outside the Basque community, leaving it open for the taking. If you’re searching for a unique name meaning dream, don’t “sleep on” Amets!

Origin: Basque

Meaning: Dream

Pronunciation: AH-mets

Popularity: Amets ranked in Spain’s top 500 names for boys in 2000 and 2010.

Anisha

When you have a good dream, the night flies by. Sometimes, it feels as though you didn’t sleep at all! Anisha captures this sentiment, meaning “nightless” or “sleepless” in Sanskrit. Anisha’s striking beauty ensures you won’t spend any “sleepless” nights worrying about your decision.

Origin: Sanskrit, Indian, Hindi

Meaning: Nightless

Namesakes: Anisha Nicole Gwynn is an R&B, hip hop, and pop singer best known for her 2002 single No Means No.

Popularity: Anisha was a top 1,000 pick in England in the early 2000s, falling out of favor by 2007.

Arian

Arian is a celestial choice on our list of dream names, typically used to describe someone born under the sign of Aries in March and April. Arian is also a variation of Aryan – an ancient ethnocultural group of Indo-Iranians who lived in northern India.

Origin: English, Persian, Indian

Meaning: Star sign of Aries, Aryan, Noble

Pronunciation: AR-ee-en

Variations: Aryan, Arya, Ariyan

Namesakes: Ariyan Arslani, better known by his stage name Action Bronson, an American rapper and television presenter.

Popularity: Arian has been in the U.S. top 1,000 since 2011, ranked 885th in 2021.

Arman

Want all of your little boy’s dreams to come true? Then, consider calling him Arman, meaning “dream,” “hope,” or “wish” in Persian. Arman also means “people of the sun,” used by foreigners as a title for the Armenian people. Choosing Arman implies your son’s future will be bright.

Origin: Persian, Armenian

Meaning: Dream, people of the sun

Pronunciation: awr-MAWN

Variations: Armen

Namesakes: Arman Manookian, an Armenian-American painter best known for depicting Hawaiian scenes.

Popularity: Arman is a top choice in Armenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, ranked in the top 50 in both countries in 2021.

Asteria

Elegant and ethereal, Asteria is an ancient Greek name belonging to the goddess of falling stars and nighttime divinations. She used her power to interpret dreams and foretell the future. Surprisingly, Asteria has never made the U.S. top 1,000, leaving this dreamy name up for grabs!

Origin: Greek

Meaning: Of the stars, starry one

Variations: Asterie

Aurora

Aurora is best known as the sleepy princess featured in Disney’s 1959 animated film Sleeping Beauty. In ancient times, Aurora was associated with the Roman goddess of the dawn, who flew across the sky each morning to make way for the sun.

Origin: Roman, Latin

Meaning: Dawn

Pronunciation: ah-RAWR-ah

Variations: Aurore, Avrora

Namesakes: Aurora Quezon, the wife of Philippine President Manuel Quezon and the first lady of the Philippines from 1935 to 1944.

Popularity: Aurora’s popularity is rising in the U.S., ranked 36th in 2020 and 2021.

Ayumu

Ayumu is an exciting choice on our list of names meaning dream, derived from the Japanese “ayu” (walk, step) and “mu” (dream, vision). The name is common in Japan but rare elsewhere. Your little dream walker won’t be afraid to explore the unknown.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Walk in a dream

Pronunciation: A-YOO-MOO

Variations: Ayumi

Namesakes: Ayumu Hirano, a Japanese three-time Olympic medalist for snowboarding.

Bhranti

In Sanskrit, Bhranti is an ideological term referencing an illusion, or when something is perceived as something else due to its similarity. Sometimes, dreams feel so real they create an illusion of reality. With a name like Bhranti, your son could be destined to have vivid, life-like dreams.

Origin: Sanskrit

Meaning: Illusion

Breksta

Breksta is a Lithuanian goddess of twilight, darkness, and dreams. She guarded her worshippers while they slept, keeping them safe from dusk till dawn. Naming your daughter after this protective goddess could keep her safe and nightmare-free whenever she closes her eyes.

Origin: Lithuanian

Meaning: It is dawning, dusk is falling

Brizo

Brizo is a little-known Greek goddess of dreams and oceans. Her name is derived from the Greek “brizein” (to fall asleep), chosen because she delivered prophecies to her worshippers while they slept. Perhaps your little Brizo will receive divine foresight each time she sleeps.

Origin: Greek

Meaning: To slumber

Caer

Caer Ibormeith was a Celtic goddess of dreams and visions, worshiped in Ireland, Scotland, and Wales. She was also a shapeshifter who would change between a swan and human forms. Caer appeared to her lover, Oengus, in his dreams each night for a year, falling in love in the dream world. A perfect name for mythology lovers!

Origin: Welsh

Meaning: Fortress

Cassandra

In Greek mythology, Cassandra was a trojan princess and seer who received the gift of prophecy from Apollo. After she spurned Apollo’s advances, he cursed her so no one would believe her visions. If Cassandra is too old-fashioned, try the modern nicknames, Cass and Cassie, instead.

Origin: Greek

Meaning: To excel, to shine

Variations: Kassandra

Namesakes: Cassandra Ventura, better known as Cassie, an American singer, model, actress, and dancer known for her singles Must Be Love, Let’s Get Crazy, and Me & U.

Popularity: Cassandra was popular for U.S. girls in the 80s and 90s, falling to 602nd in 2021.

Chayan

Chayan is a multicultural choice on our lists of names that mean dream, with origins in three countries. In Russia, Chayan comes from “chayat” (to expect, to hope, to dream), making it a cheerful option for your tiny dreamer! Chayan can be shortened to Chay for a cool, modern sound.

Origin: Russian, Tatar, Sanskrit

Meaning: Expectation, hope, dream, scorpion, life

Variations: Chaian, Chajan

Chintana

Chintana is suitable for a child with a vivid imagination, meaning “imagine” or “dream” in Thai and Lao. The name’s considered feminine in Thailand but unisex in Laos, so it’s appropriate for a baby of either gender.

Origin: Thai, Laos

Meaning: Dream

Pronunciation: cheen-ta-NA

Variations: Jintana

Namesakes: Chintana Souksavath, a Laotian football player and member of the Laos national football team.

Cimon

Kimon is an ancient name associated with a celebrated Greek military official who was crucial in Athens’ fight against the Persian empire. His name means “sleepy” because even great leaders need sleep!

Origin: Greek

Meaning: Sleepy

Variations: Kimon

Namesakes: Cimon was an Athenian statesman and general in 5th-century BC Greece.

Daimu

This exotic Japanese name is derived from the elements “dai” (big, great) and “mu” (dream). Choosing Daimu could encourage your son to dream big from the start.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Big dream

Pronunciation: DAH-EE-MU

Namesakes: Go Daimu, a South Korean football player who played for SC Sagamihara as a forward.

Daniel

In the Bible, Daniel was a prophet given the power of prophecy by God. He used his ability to interpret dreams for the King of Babylon, Nebuchadnezzar. If you’re looking for a dream-related name with religious ties, Daniel could be “the one.”

Origin: Hebrew

Meaning: God is my judge

Variations: Danilo, Danijel, Nanail, Taneli

Namesakes: Daniel Defoe, an English writer, trader, journalist, and spy, famous for his 1719 novel, Robinson Crusoe.

Popularity: Daniel is a long-standing favorite in the U.S., ranked in the top 20 since 1952.

Darshan

Darshan is a Sanskrit name commonly used by Hindi, Gujarati, and Kannada speakers in India. Darshan would suit an observant boy in touch with his dreams and ambitions. The feminine equivalent is Darshana.

Origin: Sanskrit

Meaning: Seeing, observing, understanding

Draumey

Draumey is derived from the Old Norse “draumr” (dream) combined with “ey” (island, flat land along a coast). This name is very modern, first documented in Iceland in 2008. Calling your daughter Draumey could be a great way to honor Iceland’s otherworldly beauty, so lovely it’s as if you’re dreaming!

Origin: Icelandic

Meaning: Dream island

Dream

Dream is a free-spirited girl’s name that became popular in 2017 after celebrities Rob Kardashian and Blac Chyna chose it for their daughter. Dream is trending upward, making it a fashionable choice for your little visionary.

Origin: English

Meaning: Dream

Popularity: Dream is rising in the U.S., making its way to 351st in 2021.

Drema

Drema is either an English variation of Dreama (a feminized form of Dream) or a Proto-Slavic name from “dremati” (to sleep, nap, or doze). Your little dream catcher will sleep soundly with such a gorgeous name.

Origin: English

Meaning: Dream, to sleep

Pronunciation: DREE-mah

Variations: Dreama

Dromma

Dromma is the Swedish word for “dream” derived from the Old Norse “dreyma.” If you’d like to call your daughter Dream but prefer something less apparent, Dromma could be an attractive alternative.

Origin: Swedish

Meaning: To dream

Pronunciation: DRO-ma

Durinn

Durinn is associated with a dwarf in Norse mythology who forged the famous magical sword, the Tyrfing. He was the inspiration for Durin the Deathless – the founding father of the dwarves in Tolkien’s Middle-earth. If we learned anything from Sleepy in Snow White, it’s that dwarves love to take a nap! Perhaps your son will sleep as soundly as a dwarf.

Origin: Norse

Meaning: Sleepy one

Variations: Durin

Dwalin

A mythical choice on our list of dream names, Dwalin is the name of a brave dwarf character in J.R.R. Tolkien’s book, The Hobbit. His name is derived from the Old Norse “dvalen” (to sleep). Maybe your son, Dwalin, will go on grand adventures when he dreams, just like a Tolkien character.

Origin: Germanic

Meaning: Sleeping

Pronunciation: DWAL-in

Endri

Endri is derived from “enderr” – an Albanian word from the Proto-Indo-European “dreh” (sleep, to sleep). Or, it may be an alternate interpretation of the Albanian Endrit (enlightened). Endri’s connection to enlightenment and dreams suggests your son will be an observer who understands the world on a deeper level.

Origin: Albanian

Meaning: Dream, enlightened

Namesakes: Endri Fuga, an Albanian politician and director of communications for Prime Minister Edi Rama.

Erebus

Erebus was a primordial deity of darkness and shadows in Greek mythology. His name was later used for a region in the Greek underworld, where the dead would go immediately after dying. Naming your son after this god could alleviate his fear of the dark.

Origin: Greek

Meaning: Deep darkness, shadows

Pronunciation: AIR-ruh-buhs

Variations: Erebos

Fantasia

Playful and distinctive, Fantasia comes directly from the English word fantasy (AKA imagining things that are unlikely to occur in the real world). Whenever your daughter Fantasia dreams, she’ll be able to make all of her greatest fantasies come true.

Origin: English

Meaning: Fantasy

Pronunciation: fan-TAY-see-uh

Namesakes: Fantasia Burino, an American R&B singer and actress who won the third season of American Idol in 2004.

Fursey

Fursey is associated with a medieval Irish monk and seer who had angelic visions of the afterlife. His dreams deeply affected religious thought in Western Europe, as seen in Dante’s famous poem, Divine Comedy. Selecting Fursey could give your son the foresight of this powerful visionary.

Origin: Irish

Meaning: Virtue

Variations: Fursy, Furseus, Furcy, Fursa, Forseus

Gabriel

In the Bible, Gabriel was an angel who came to Mary in a dream to tell her she would be the mother of Jesus. Gabriel also interpreted the visions of the prophet Daniel in the Old Testament. Gabriel’s Christian ties could make it the perfect dream name for a religious family.

Origin: Hebrew

Meaning: God is my strong man

Namesakes: Gabriel Byrne, an Irish actor and film director featured in Excalibur (1981), End of Days (1999), Vampire Academy (2014), and Hereditary (2018).

Popularity: Gabriel is a timeless classic in the U.S., ranked in the top 500 boys’ names since 1908.

Goda

Goda is rare, except in Lithuania, where it’s been a top 20 girls’ name since 2006. It has two meanings in Lithuania: “dream” and “honor.” Perhaps your daughter’s beautiful dreams will earn her honor and glory.

Origin: Lithuanian, Indian, Japanese

Meaning: Dream, honor, connected rice paddies

Popularity: Goda was ranked as Lithuania’s 18th most popular girl’s name in 2021.

Goyathlay

Goyathlay is the anglicized form of the Apache name Goyaale (one who yawns). This was the actual name of the legendary 19th-century Apache leader, Geronimo. Although complex, Goyathlay’s cute meaning and powerful namesake might be worth the effort.

Origin: Apache

Meaning: One who yawns

Pronunciation: gaw-YAHT-leye

Variations: Goyaale

Namesakes: Goyathlay (aka Geronimo), was the chief of the Bedonkohe band of the Chiricahua Apaches and one of the driving forces during the Apache Wars.

Guifi

Guifi comes from the Chamorro indigenous peoples who reside on the Mariana Islands in the western Pacific. It’s technically gender-neutral but most often given to females. If you want an exotic dream name with very few bearers, Guifi could be a keeper.

Origin: Chamorro

Meaning: Dream

Pronunciation: GUI-FEE

Hayal

Hayal is an elegant choice on our list of names meaning dream, derived from the Arabic “kayal” (dream, wish). Other possible meanings are “fantasy,” “illusion,” or “imagination.” The name’s primarily used by the Turkish and the Crimean Tatar population in Crimea. Hayal’s adorable nickname, Hay, could give Hailey a run for its money.

Origin: Turkish, Arabic

Meaning: Dream

Pronunciation: hai-AL

Namesakes: Hayal Koseoglu, a Turkish TV actress known for her role as Derya in the 2017 series, Ufak Tefek Cinayetler.

Hilmi

Hilmi is either derived from the Arabic “hilm” (forbearance, tolerance, endurance) or “hulm” (dream, wish). Hilmi is typically masculine but is occasionally given to girls in Indonesia. Youthful and friendly, Hilmi could be a charming option for your tiny dreamer.

Origin: Arabic

Meaning: Dream, endurance

Pronunciation: HEEL-mee

Variations: Hilmie, Hilmy, Helmi, Helmy

Namesakes: Hilmi Mihci, a Dutch former soccer player of Turkish descent.

Hypnos

In Greek mythology, Hypnos was the personification of sleep. He was a calm and benevolent god who helped humans rest at night. Your little Hypnos’s gentle soul will be as soothing as a lullaby.

Origin: Greek

Meaning: Sleep

Ikelos

In Ovid’s Metamorphoses, Ikelos was a son of Nyx – the goddess of darkness. Ikelos was the god of nightmares who often appeared in dreams as a lion or bear. Your little Ikelos will learn to control his nightmares – not the other way around.

Origin: Greek

Meaning: Like, resembling

Pronunciation: eye-key-LOS

Variations: Icelus, Icelos

Illusia

Illusia was invented in 1944 by Finnish author Yrjo Kokko for his fairy tale, Pessi, and Illusia. In the story, Illusia is the fairy daughter of Mr Illusioni – a prominent visionary who lives on a rainbow. Illusia falls in love with a pessimistic goblin named Pessi and changes his outlook on life. Like Illusia, your daughter’s dreamy personality could brighten the lives of others around her.

Origin: Finnish

Meaning: Illusion

Isleen

While the exact origins of Isleen is uncertain, many scholars believe it’s the anglicized form of Aisling – a modern Irish name meaning “dream” or “vision.” Isleen is rare, making it a creative option for your tiny dream catcher.

Origin: Irish

Meaning: Dream

Pronunciation: I-sleen, IS-leen

Variations: Aisling

Jareth

Jareth is an invented name played by David Bowie in the 1986 movie the Labyrinth. In the film, Jareth is a powerful Goblin king to whom the protagonist, Sarah Williams, wishes away her baby brother. She regrets her decision and must travel through a dreamworld in 13 hours to save her brother. Jareth could be an excellent choice for a bold boy with a wild imagination.

Origin: English

Meaning: Unknown

Joseph

In the Bible, Joseph was the favorite son of Jacob, who had prophetic dreams about his future. He was sometimes called Joseph the Dreamer. Your son Joseph could also be blessed with the gift of foresight and wisdom.

Origin: Hebrew

Meaning: He will add

Variations: Yosef, Josef

Popularity: Joseph is a long-standing favorite in the U.S., ranked in the top 50 names for boys since 1900.

Kalpana

Let your daughter’s imagination flourish by naming her Kalpana! This name is prevalent throughout India, especially among speakers of Tamil, Kannada, Telugu, Nepali, and Hindi. Use nicknames Kal or Ana to make Kalpana more casual.

Origin: Sanskrit

Meaning: Imagining, fantasy

Namesakes: Kalpana Chawla, an Indian-born American astronaut and the first woman of Indian origin to go to space.

Kamari

Kamari is a prominent name within the U.S. African-American community. It was adopted from the Swahili Kamaria, which, in turn, came from the Arabic “qamar” (moon). Kamari is technically unisex but is more common for males. Calling your little guy Kamari will give him an instant connection to the moon, night, and dreams.

Origin: Swahili, Arabic

Meaning: Moon

Pronunciation: ka-ma-REE

Variations: Kamaria

Popularity: Kamari has risen in popularity for U.S. boys since the early 2000s, ranked 391st in 2021.

Kanae

Kanae is derived from the verb “kanaeru” (come true). Choosing this name for your daughter implies she won’t be afraid to chase her dreams and make them a reality! Although Kanae is technically unisex, it’s almost exclusively given to females in Japan, with several famous athletes and actresses bearing the name.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Come true, fine, blessed, seedlings

Pronunciation: KAH-NAE-EE

Namesakes: Kanae Ito, a Japanese voice actress, and singer featured in the series To Love-Ru, The World God Only Knows, Hanasaku Iroha, and A Certain Scientific Railgun.

Khoni

Khoni is an unusual name used by the Nenets – an indigenous people group native to northern Arctic Russia. Choose Khoni, and you’ll sleep soundly knowing your daughter has such a lovely and unique name.

Origin: Nenets

Meaning: Sleepy

Pronunciation: kuh-OONI

Kokin

Kokin comes from the Nivkh people – an indigenous ethnic group inhabiting Sakhalin island and the adjacent Russian coast. Your son can rest easy with this youthful and relaxed name.

Origin: Nivkh

Meaning: Sleep

Lorien

Fantasy lovers will appreciate Lorien’s connection to the elven city featured in J.R.R. Tolkien’s famous saga, The Lord of the Rings. The city was the most beautiful place in the world, with silver willows, gorgeous flowers, and pristine lakes. Lorien is believed to mean “land of gold” or “dream flower” – picturesque titles describing the area’s otherworldly beauty.

Origin: English

Meaning: Dreamflower

Lotus

In Greek and Roman mythology, the Lotus-eaters were a race of people who only ate the magical lotus fruit, which caused sleepiness and forgetfulness. The fruit would remove all of their worries, leaving them tired but content. Giving your daughter an elegant name like Lotus could take her worries away.

Origin: English

Meaning: Water lily, lotus tree

Namesakes: Lotus Long, an Asian-American film actress during the 1930s who paved the way for future Asian actresses in Hollywood.

Popularity: Lotus was a common girls’ name in the Netherlands in the early 2000s, reaching its peak of 168th in 2009.

Lourdes

Lourdes is the name of a French town associated with Bernadette Soubirous – a young seer who had visions of the Virgin Mary. Calling your daughter Lourdes implies she could have a connection to the spiritual world beyond.

Origin: French, Spanish

Meaning: Unknown

Pronunciation: LOORDZ, LOOR-dhehs

Luna

In ancient Roman mythology, Luna was the divine embodiment of the moon depicted driving a white chariot through the sky. She had the power to mask reality, awaken intuition, and cause visions. Luna could also send her worshippers solutions to their problems while they were dreaming.

Origin: Roman

Meaning: Moon

Namesakes: Luna Schweiger, a German actress best known for her role in the 2007 film Keinohrhasen.

Popularity: Luna is very trendy in the U.S., ranked as the 11th most popular girl’s name in 2021.

Mamu

Mamu was the Mesopotamian goddess of dreams. Her name comes from the Sumerian word “mamu,” explicitly referencing dreams with the capacity to influence the future. Your little Mamu’s powerful visions could shape her reality.

Origin: Sumerian

Meaning: Dream

Variations: Mamud

Marimu

Marimu comes from the Japanese “mari” (sea, ocean) combined with “mu” (dream). Marimu is soft and delicate, lulling your daughter to sleep like the ocean’s waves. An adorable nickname is Mari.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Ocean of dream, ten thousand, village

Pronunciation: mah-REE-mu

Maya

Maya is a fundamental concept in Hinduism, referencing how the physical world is an illusion, which one must overcome to achieve Brahman, AKA absolute truth or consciousness. Maya is also an epithet for Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth and love.

Origin: Sanskrit, English, Hebrew

Meaning: Illusion, magic

Variations: Maia

Namesakes: Maya Angelou, an American memoirist, poet, and civil rights activist best known for her first autobiographical book, I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings (1969).

Popularity: Maya is a popular choice for U.S. girls, ranked 55th in 2021.

Meng

Meng is a unique choice among our names that mean dream, traditionally used as a surname. In recent years, it’s become a common first name, especially for girls. Meng could be the answer if you’ve been “dreaming” of calling your daughter something cute yet unexpected.

Origin: Chinese

Meaning: Dream

Pronunciation: MUNG

Namesakes: Meng Tian, a Chinese inventor and military general of the Qin dynasty who helped construct the Great Wall of China.

Mimoza

Mimoza is the Albanian form of mimosa – a plant species whose foliage closes at dark and reopens at first light. Like the plant, your little Mimoza will close her eyes each night before awakening to the morning light.

Origin: Spanish

Meaning: To imitate

Variations: Mimosa

Namesakes: Mimoza Kusari-Lila, an Albanian Kosovar politician for The Alternative.

Moeroa

Moeroa is a typical surname in the Cook Islands, derived from the Maori words “moe” (sleep) and “roa” (long). It’s also occasionally used as a given name. If you like Moeroa but want a casual nickname for everyday use, give Moe or Ro a try.

Origin: Maori

Meaning: Long sleep

Namesakes: Tepai Moeroa, a Cook Islands professional rugby player who plays as a prop, lock, or second-rower for the Melbourne Storm.

Moon

A perfect choice for nature lovers, Moon is derived from the Greek “men” for “month.” Or, it may come from the Latin “metiri,” meaning “to measure,” referencing how the moon is used as a measure of time. The moon is often linked to sleep and dreaming, making this a fabulous “honorable mention” on our list of dream names.

Origin: English, Germanic, Greek, Latin, Korean, Dutch

Meaning: Month, to measure, letters, one

Namesakes: Aubrey Wilson Mullican, known professionally as Moon Mullican, an American country and western singer called the “King of the Hillbilly Piano Players.”

Morpheus

In Greek mythology, Morpheus was the god of dreams. His name is derived from the Greek word for “shape” (morphe), referencing the forms seen in dreams. Morpheus is powerful and bold – just like your son’s imagination will likely be!

Origin: Greek

Meaning: Shape

Pronunciation: MAWR-fee-us

Nayu

Give your little one the courage to find love and follow her dreams by naming her Nayu. Nayu is derived from the Japanese “na” (love, affection) combined with “yu” (dream).

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Love and dreams

Pronunciation: NAH-YOO

Nemu

Looking for an adorable name for your tiny dream walker, then consider Nemu? It’s more common in fiction than in real life and is often associated with several anime characters. The most prominent is Nemu Kurotsuchi, an artificially created woman in the series, Bleach.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Sleep, dream

Pronunciation: NEH-MOO

Nidra

Nidra is a Hindu goddess of night. She helps those who suffer from sleeplessness, tiredness, and lack of energy. While naming your daughter Nidra won’t ensure she’ll sleep well every night, it certainly doesn’t hurt.

Origin: Sanskrit

Meaning: Unknown

Niorun

Niorun is a minor Norse goddess whom little is known about. In mythology, it’s said that the dwarves referred to night as Draum-Njorn (Dream-Niorun), leading some to believe that Niorun was the goddess of sleeping and dreams.

Origin: Norse

Meaning: Unknown

Variations: Njorun

Nisa

Nisa is an uncomplicated girls’ name primarily used in Thailand, derived from the Sanskrit “Nisha” (night). Nisa is also an Arabic name meaning “women,” associated with the fourth chapter of the Quran, referencing women’s laws and issues (Surah an-Nisa).

Origin: Thai, Sanskrit, Turkish

Meaning: Night, women

Pronunciation: nee-SAH

Variations: Neesa

Namesakes: Nisa Godrej, a chairperson of Godrej Consumer Products.

Popularity: Nisa is most popular in Turkey, ranked 37th in 2021.

Nott

In Norse mythology, Nott was the personification of night. She was the mother of Dagr – the personification of day. This name is scarce today, with few modern bearers. Choosing Nott for your little night watcher ensures she’ll be anything but ordinary!

Origin: Norse

Meaning: Night

Variations: Nótt

Nyx

Nyx was the Greek goddess of the night represented as a shadowy figure of a woman. She was the mother of other personified deities, such as Hypnos (god of sleep), Thanatos (god of death), and Erebus (god of darkness). Nyx’s short length and unique sound should make it a hit among your peers.

Origin: Greek

Meaning: Night

Pronunciation: NIKS

Oneiroi

In Greek mythology, the Oneiroi were dark-winged dream spirits who resided in the caves of Erebus – a place in the underworld. They would pass through a gate made of a horn to send prophetic dreams or one made of ivory to send meaningless dreams.

Origin: Greek

Pronunciation: OH-NEAR-oy

Oniria

Oniria is a recently invented name derived from the Spanish word “onirica” (dreamlike, oneiric). Oniria is a dreamy name for your dream come true.

Origin: Spanish

Meaning: Dreamlike

Pronunciation: o-NEER-ya

Namesakes: Oniria Gutierrez, a Cuban revolutionary who joined Che Guevara.

Pasithea

Take your daughter’s stress away by naming her Pasithea, after the Greek goddess of rest and relaxation. This ancient name can be shortened to Thea for a modern update.

Origin: Greek

Meaning: Goddess of all

Pronunciation: pa-sith-EE-ah

Variations: Pasithee

Phantom

A Phantom is an apparition, often likened to a ghost. The word can also refer to a fantasy or an illusion. Cartoon fans may appreciate the connection to the ghost-hunting superhero, Danny Phantom.

Origin: English

Meaning: Ghost, dream, fantasy

Ragnhild

The Norse took dreams very seriously. This was especially true in the case of Queen Ragnhild, who dreamed about a tree whose branches spread across all of Norway and into other lands. Later, Ragnhild discovered the tree represented her descendants, who would come to rule Norway for many generations.

Origin: Old Norse

Meaning: Advice, counsel, battle

Variations: Ragnhildr, Reinhild, Raganhildis

Namesakes: Ragnhild Tove Hveger, a Danish swimmer who set 44 world records from 1936 to 1943.

Ratri

Ratri is a Hindu goddess and personification of the night. She is the sister of Ushas, goddess of the dawn. If you like names relating to nature, go for the Ratree spelling instead.

Origin: Sanskrit, Thai

Meaning: Night

Pronunciation: ra-TREE

Variations: Ratree, Rathri

Remiel

Remiel is an archangel known for giving people divine visions and guiding faithful souls to heaven. He is also called Jeremiel or Uriel in other translations of the Bible. Perhaps your little Remiel will be blessed with incredible foresight.

Origin: Hebrew

Meaning: Thunder of God

Reverie

An elegant choice among our names meaning dream, Reverie is derived from the Old French “resver” (to dream, to rave). Reverie is beautiful in full or when paired with the cute nicknames Rev and Revie.

Origin: English, French

Meaning: Daydream

Pronunciation: REHV-ah-ree

Rowan

In Celtic tradition, the rowan tree was viewed as a symbol of protection which would keep evil spirits away. Choosing Rowan could help keep the nightmares far away from your son.

Origin: Irish, English

Meaning: Red

Pronunciation: RO-en

Namesakes: Rowan Williams, a Welsh Anglican bishop, theologian, and poet.

Popularity: Rowan’s on the rise in England and Wales, ranked 71st in 2020.

Roya

Roya comes from the Persian “royâ” (dream), of Arabic origin. Roya is simple yet distinctive, offering your little dream watcher a name as unique as she is.

Origin: Persian, Arabic

Meaning: Dream

Variations: Ruya

Namesakes: Roya Arab, a UK-based Iranian musician, and archaeologist.

Sanders

Although Sanders doesn’t mean “dream,” its relation to the sandman – a mythical spirit who sprinkles magic sand on people’s eyes to help bring good dreams – is too cute to pass up! Sanders is typically used as a surname, making it a unique first name option for your little guy.

Origin: English, Greek

Meaning: Defending man

Namesakes: Colonel Harland Sanders, founder of the American fast-food chicken restaurant Kentucky Fried Chicken.

Sanja

Sanja comes from the South Slavic “sanjati” (dream). It’s widespread in South-Eastern Europe, especially in the six countries making up the former Yugoslavia. Sanja’s soft sound and elegant spelling make it a dreamy choice for your baby on the way.

Origin: Slavic

Meaning: Dream

Pronunciation: SAN-yah

Variations: Sanjica

Namesakes: Sanja Vucic, a lead vocalist in the Serbian crossover band ZAA.

Popularity: Sanja was common in Slovenia in the early 2000s, falling out of the top 100 in 2008.

Sapna

Sapna is an unusual choice on our list of names that mean dream, primarily used by Hindi speakers in India. The nickname Sap (like tree sap) may appeal to nature lovers.

Origin: Indian

Meaning: Sleep, dream

Variations: Swapna

Namesakes: Sapna Chaudhary, an Indian actress, singer and dancer who rose to fame after participating in the Indian reality TV show Bigg Boss.

Sarka

Sarka hails from a Czech legend, born by a woman who declared war against men. She tied herself to a tree, and after the men came to her rescue, she offered them mead laced with a sleep potion. No one will mess with your little Sarka!

Origin: Czech

Meaning: Unknown

Pronunciation: SHAR-ka

Popularity: Sarka remained in the Czech Republic’s top 100 girls’ names from 1945 to 2016.

Selene

In Greek myths, Selene was the goddess of the moon, often depicted driving her white chariot across the sky. Her name is derived from the Greek noun “selas” (light, brightness or gleam).

Origin: Greek

Meaning: Moon

Namesakes: Selene Luna, a Mexican-American actress, comedian, and burlesque performer.

Popularity: Selene re-entered the U.S. charts in 2017, rising to 721st in 2021.

Sidra

Sidra is an Arabic name meaning “goddess of stars” or “like a star.” It’s also a variation of Sidrah, meaning “lotus tree” – a symbolic plant that sits on the outermost boundary of heaven. It’s believed that no one can enter this divine realm except Allah and the prophet Muhammad.

Origin: Pakistani, Arabic

Meaning: Lotus tree, goddess of the stars

Namesakes: Sidra Sadaf, a Pakistani woman cyclist and silver-medalist at the 11th South Asian Games in 2010.

Sigmund

Sigmund is inextricably linked to Sigmund Freud – a prominent psychologist known for his theories of the unconscious mind and interpretation of dreams. The German pronunciation is ZEEK-mund, lending itself to the cool nickname, Ziggy.

Origin: Germanic

Meaning: Protector of victory

Variations: Siegmund, Sigismund

Namesakes: Sigmund Freud, an Austrian psychologist, and creator of psychoanalysis.

Popularity: Sigmund fell out of the U.S. top 1,000 names for boys in 1926.

Somnus

Somnus is a mythical option on our list of dream names associated with the Roman personification of sleep. He had a thousand sons called the Somnia (aka dream shapes) who would appear as different objects and animals in the dream world. Somnus is mysterious and unusual – appealing to unique name enthusiasts.

Origin: Roman

Meaning: Sleep

Sovanna

Sovanna is a Khmer name derived from the Sanskrit “suvarna” (bright, gold). This pleasant name might bless your daughter with beautiful dreams. In the U.S., Sovanna could be a creative Savanna alternative.

Origin: Khmer

Meaning: Golden dream

Pronunciation: so-VON-nah

Svajone

This pretty Lithuanian name references a person’s hopes and dreams- the kind of dreams experienced while sleeping. Although Svajone is unpopular outside its home country, its uniqueness might suit your daughter’s imaginative spirit.

Origin: Lithuanian

Meaning: Dream

Pronunciation: SO-VAH-YONE

Swapnil

Swapnil is derived from the Sanskrit “svapna” (sleep, dream). If you’re having boy-girl twins, consider pairing Swapnil with its dreamy female equivalent, Swapna.

Origin: Indian

Meaning: Sleep, dream

Pronunciation: SWAP-nuhl

Namesakes: Swapnil, an Indian film and TV actor featured in Krishna, Eka Lagnachi Dusri Goshta, and Comedy Circus.

Van

Van’s association with sleep and dreaming comes from Rip Van Winkle, a character created by author Washington Irving. In the story, Rip Van Winkle meets a mysterious Dutchman who offers him a drink which causes him to fall asleep for 20 years. If Van is too informal, go for longer Vance or Ivan.

Origin: English

Meaning: Marsh, Yahweh is gracious

Wasan

Wasan is a poetic option on our list of names meaning dream, describing the last moments of wakefulness before drifting off to sleep. Your little Wasan will rest peacefully with such an elegant name.

Origin: Arabic

Meaning: Last moments before sleep

Variations: Wassan

Winta

Bless your daughter with the gift of good dreams by naming her Winta. This name is from the Amharic language, primarily spoken in Ethiopia. Winta is also Tigrinya (an Afro-Asiatic language) name meaning “need.”

Origin: Amharic

Meaning: Dream gift, desire

Yuho

Yuho comes from the Japanese “yu” (dream, evening) combined with “ho” (walk, star). Whether your daughter is as free as a dream walker or bright as the evening star, Yuho captures her essence.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Dream walk, evening star

Namesakes: Yuho Iwasato, a prominent Japanese songwriter whose songs have featured in several anime series.

Yume

A youthful option among our names that mean dream, Yume is often interpreted to mean “dream” or “vision” in Japanese. However, it can also mean “abundant,” “plentiful,” “bud,” or “sprout.” Yume could be an attractive choice for an American girl of Japanese descent.

Origin: Japanese

Meaning: Dream

Pronunciation: YOO-MEH

Namesakes: Yume Miyamoto, a Japanese voice actress known for her roles as Megumi Amatsuka in GJ Club and Lilo in the Japanese dub of Lilo and Stitch.

Zorya

In Slavic folklore, Zorya is the beautiful goddess of the dawn and the daughter of the sun god Dazbog. She transforms from Zorya Utrennyaya (goddess of the morning star) to Zorya Vechernyaya (goddess of the evening star) to Zorya (goddess of midnight) as the day passes. Z names are very trendy right now, ensuring Zorya will be a big hit!

Origin: Slavic

Meaning: Dawn

Variations: Zarya, Zara, Zaranitsa, Zoryushka

Zulhelmi

Zulhelmi is derived from the Arabic “dhu” (possessor of) combined with “hulm” (dream, wish). With so many spelling variations, at least one form of Zulhelmi is likely to suit your tiny master of dreams.

Origin: Arabic, Malay, Indonesian

Meaning: Possessor of dreams

Pronunciation: zool-HELL-me

Variations: Zul Helmi, Zulhelmy, Zulhelmie, Zulhelmee, Dzulhelmi, Dzulhelmy, Dzulhelmee, Dzulhelmie

Namesakes: Zulhelmi Pisol, a Malaysian weightlifter.
